title: RELICT: A Replica Detection Framework for Medical Image Generation
author: Orhun Utku Aydin (Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin), Alexander Koch (Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin), Adam Hilbert (Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin), Jana Rieger (Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin), Felix Lohrke (Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin), Fujimaro Ishida (Mie Chuo Medical Center), Satoru Tanioka (Mie University Graduate School of Medicine), ..., Dietmar Frey (Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin)
background: The task focuses on detecting nearly identical copies of training data within synthetic medical images to enhance privacy and ethical usage in medical imaging applications.
contribution: RELICT introduces a multi-faceted framework for replica detection using voxel-level analysis, feature extraction via a foundation model, and segmentation comparison, effectively identifying replicas in synthetic medical images.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior approaches to medical image generation lacked standardized methods for replica detection, often employing ad-hoc solutions or focusing on specific tasks.
technical_comparison.novelty: This framework integrates multiple methods for comprehensive similarity evaluation, significantly improving the robustness of detecting potential privacy vulnerabilities.

key_innovation: Combines different analytical approaches for a more comprehensive assessment of synthetic images against training data, thus enhancing the utility and ethical handling of generated medical images.
real_world_impact: The RELICT framework promises to bolster patient privacy by ensuring that synthetic medical images do not replicate identifiable patient information, thereby facilitating safer AI applications in healthcare.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention significant limitations, but the performance of replica detection may vary based on the specific context or type of medical imaging.

new_terms.replica detection: **Replica detection** refers to the process of identifying synthetic images that closely resemble original training samples, posing risks of privacy loss and ethical concerns.

open_sourcing: The tools and frameworks developed for this research are available at https://github.com/claim-berlin/relict.
